Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)

This isn't a terribly strongly held opinion, but if we're aiming to make it more flexible should we maybe just go ahead and make it a runtime option via a command-line flag?  The buffer is dynamically allocated anyway, so it's not like it would add new potential points of failure, and it wouldn't be all that much additional code...
Sure, it's about the same effort. I think runtime argument makes sense, too. Done making it in the config file like the way log size is specified.
Hi Medicine, thanks for the patch. I've made a few comments inline.
I'd prefer we make the change of the symbol name a separate patch to introducing the new config property.
Done making a separate function so that the pattern is one function entry per-config.

`buffer_size_str` will be `NULL` if `ringbuffer-size` is not specified in the config. `config_parse_bytesize()` returns `-1` if the provided `buffer_size_str` is `NULL`. If `ringbuffer-size` is unspecified then we want to set `buffer_size = default_buffer_size`, but the condition here appears to prevent that.

Have you tested this path? Can you demonstrate it works correctly?

I followed the pattern of existing codes (log-handler.c:145) and assigned the default value when declaring buffer_size at the top.

The default value assignment is too far away. It's not so clear that the default value applies so let me put it down here instead. Note that it's by design avoiding warning message if a config is not set at all.

I've tested it already. Here is demonstration of the output.

```
$ echo '' > test.conf && ./obmc-console-server --config test.conf /dev/ttyS1
TEST ONLY: ringbuffer-size: 128kB
3 handlers
  log [active]
  socket [active]
  tty [inactive]
^CReceived interrupt, exiting
$ echo 'ringbuffer-size = ' > test.conf && ./obmc-console-server --config test.conf /dev/ttyS1
TEST ONLY: ringbuffer-size: 128kB
3 handlers
  log [active]
  socket [active]
  tty [inactive]
^CReceived interrupt, exiting
$ echo 'ringbuffer-size = 1MB' > test.conf && ./obmc-console-server --config test.conf /dev/ttyS1
TEST ONLY: ringbuffer-size: 1024kB
3 handlers
  log [active]
  socket [active]
  tty [inactive]
^CReceived interrupt, exiting
$ echo 'ringbuffer-size = 1MM' > test.conf && ./obmc-console-server --config test.conf /dev/ttyS1
obmc-console-server: Invalid suffix!: Success
obmc-console-server: Invalid ringbuffer-size. Default to 128kB: Success
TEST ONLY: ringbuffer-size: 128kB
3 handlers
  log [active]
  socket [active]
  tty [inactive]
^CReceived interrupt, exiting
$ echo 'ringbuffer-size = 1kB' > test.conf && ./obmc-console-server --config test.conf /dev/ttyS1
TEST ONLY: ringbuffer-size: 1kB
3 handlers
  log [active]
  socket [active]
  tty [inactive]
obmc-console-server: /usr/src/debug/obmc-console/1.0+git/console-server.c:843: run_console: Assertion `sizeof(buf) <= console->rb->size' failed.
Aborted (core dumped)
```
`%zu` and drop the cast?
Done
This hunk is unnecessary now.
Done.
Perhaps adding a `NULL` test would be helpful :)
Done
Hi Medicine, a couple more comments inline.

Hmm. This wasn't really what I was asking for. You'd already done all the work to rename `config_parse_logsize()` to something more sensible in the previous PS. I think that's still the right approach, I suggesting it's my preferences that you do it in a separate, earlier commit to introducing the new config option, as it caused a bit of noise in the patch.

The latest approach here is papering over the problem rather than fixing it. Given this is an open source project we tend to aim for what's good rather than what's easy - can you please include the cleanup in the original style, but in a separate patch?
Thanks for the explanation. I've fixed that with another commit like you mentioned. I thought you don't like a common feature name and prefer the per-config function name.
You're right, this works fine and is more clear.

Just to confirm, this will result in showing warning message when this config is not set. I'm don't think users wants to see that this is not assigned by default since it's not a required option.

Is this okay to you? or do we want to simply move the default value assignment closer to this if condition.

That's a fair point, however you could guard the warning with

```
if (buffer_size_str != NULL) {
    warn(...)
```
Sure, that sounds okay to me. Thanks for your helps.

See the comment about the guard for the `warn()` invocation above:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/obmc-console/+/69987/comment/c65066be_2ada8db6/
Done
Hi Andrew, is there any action item for a +2
Done
Any particular reason not to use `%zu` here instead of `%u` and a cast?
Not really. I copied this code from other `log-handler.c:148`. I thought it's just preference to this project. Updated to zu instead.
Looks good in general, just a few comments on implementation details.
this will disappear on NDEBUG; we probably want this to be checked at configuration time.
What does configuration time mean? This ring buffer size is assigned at run time. There is no way to check this at compile time with static assert.

As the size can now change at runtime you need to perform the error handling at runtime. You need to convert the `assert()` into an `if (buf > console->rb->size) { /* handle the error */ }`.

Supplying `-DNDEBUG` to the compiler elides all `assert()` invocations from the source:

> If the macro NDEBUG is defined at the moment <assert.h> was last
> included, the macro assert() generates no code, and hence does
> nothing at all.  It is not recommended to define NDEBUG if using
> assert() to detect error conditions since the software may behave
> non-deterministically.

https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/assert.3.html

Essentially, assertions are not a substitution for error handling.
Done. Convert that to run time detection.
Super minor, but can you keep the reverse-christmas-tree formatting here?
Not perfect but done. Unless you prefer to touch unrelated lines here to make the tree looks perfect.

This logic seems a bit backwards; if ringbuffer-size is not specified, you parse anyway, then conditionally ignore the error.

Could you flip this to make the parse conditional instead? Just set the default beforehand.

Updated. In order to achieve this. This code will be updated back to its original form. I think we should pick one coding style and not make changes any more. I'm starting to loop the ways of writing these lines of codes.

In the updated version, assigning the default value again inside the if-condition is necessary because it's weird to guarantee that the pointer value is not touched when rc returns non-zero errors despite that's how this is currently implemented. From my understanding, without loss of generality, when rc is non-zero, that pointer value should be undefined behavior.

What's your thoughts?
That looks better. Thanks
We should probably have `rc = -1` or similar here so that if we actually hit this error path `run_console()` doesn't spuriously return 0 (success) to its caller.
Good point. Done.
friendly ping
